Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Elaine Lee of the University of Pennsylvania to conduct a research project, entitled "Patterned polymeric materials for cell studies," during the summer of 2012 at Seoul National University in Seoul, Korea. The host scientist is Dr. Kahp-Yang Suh.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to understand cell behavior on man-made materials which can respond to the environment. Using novel fabrication techniques, micro- and nano-scale features can be patterned on soft, polymeric materials to mimic the natural environment of the cells. This project aims to understand how changing the physical properties of the materials will affect cell size, shape, function and behavior.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the global population finally hits the seven-billion mark this year, the design of more energy-efficient buildings is ever-critical. For the sustenance of an ever-growing population in a world with limited energy resources, “smart building skins” can help alleviate this strain by minimizing a building’s energy consumption in response to environmental triggers. To address this, the goal of my research project is to design and engineer materials for responsive building skins at the architectural scale, using insights gained from interfacing human cells with active, geometrically-defined soft materials in a 4-D setting (spatially and temporally). The insights as to how cells can modify their immediate microenvironment with minimal energy and maximal effect will lead to the biomimetic design and engineering of passive materials, which will be integrated into smart sensors and optical/electrical circuits for new paradigms of responsive building skins. 

To this end, I have been working to design polymeric substrates with various mechanical and optical properties, which can be changed in response to a variety of external stimuli. Using different techniques, I have fabricated well-defined geometrical patterns (1D-3D), composed of flexible, environmentally-responsive polymers as substrates for cell studies. These materials will allow me to apply external forces to the underlying substrate, triggering responses in the material as well as cell morphology and function. So far, few groups have created active substrates. By surveying cell morphologies on various hierarchically patterned substrates and extracting the biological cues of how cells response to the environmental and material changes, we can draw inspiration to design responsive materials for dynamic tuning of their physical properties. While my lab (under Prof. Shu Yang) in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania has expertise in materials fabrication techniques, we have had limited experience in culturing and seeding cells.

Thus, through the NSF EAPSI program, I was able to work with Prof. Kahp Y. Suh and his group in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Seoul National University in South Korea on the culture and morphological study of cells on polymeric substrates. I was lucky enough to learn from Laura Ha, who is a master’s student in the laboratory who is a U.S. citizen who has spent half her life in South Korea. Throughout my time in Korea, she acted as a bridge to the other students as well as the professor and other Koreans. Through this project, Prof. Suh's group and I have been able to share our experiences and techniques in micro- and nano-patterning of polymer systems. While these techniques often seem similar in publications, all labs have developed 'tricks' and tweaks for better pattern fabrication and we have mutually benefited from our time together. In addition, I was able to learn many techniques for the assembly of microfluidic devices and the culture and morphological study of cells on polymeric substrates, which I had no previous experience with. It was a very tedious process to learn, especially since most of the standard protocols were written in Korean.

In addition, I was able to secure housing through the Gwanak Homestay Program, which allowed me ample opportunity to interact with native Koreans on a daily basis. I stayed with Kim Chunran and her family, sharing meals and experiences daily. Together, we traveled to Gong-ju to explore ancient Shilla and other Three Kingdom cultural sites.
